reasonings_12: 1. (YES) In a representative democracy, parliament is the primary institution for expressing consent; thus, if consent is essential, parliament must accurately represent the will of the people. 2. (NO) Consent can be achieved through various mechanisms (e.g., direct democracy, monarchy), not necessarily requiring accurate parliamentary representation. 3. (NO) Argument 1 discusses consent in the context of monarchy, not representative institutions, so Statement 1 derived from it does not entail a modern parliamentary requirement.
comment_12: I am moderately confident because while there is a plausible link in democratic theory, Statement 1 is a general principle that does not strictly necessitate the specific institutional requirement in Statement 2.
